awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Blind information measures for waves: a deterministic approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the study of signal representation and reconstruction in the context of sensing and communication. Non-redundant representation of signals is a key issue to perform sensing efficiently and to achieve optimal communication rates. In many practical scenarios, one would want to perform sensing with a small number of measurements, often with partial or incomplete knowledge of the structure of the signal. Specifically, for signals occupying disjoint sub-intervals of the spectral band, knowledge of the number and locations of the sub-bands is typically assumed. This project investigates ways to relax these assumptions at the cost of performing a slightly larger number of measurements. There are several potential benefits arising from this research. Results will lead to insights on optimal sensing and communication architectures, as well as provide fundamental limits of these architectures. The project also introduces new mathematical methods and, in laying the foundations for the wave theory of information, it draws connections between information theory, functional approximation, and compressed sensing. On the education front, it involves students in the research, as well as recruitment efforts for under-represented groups. 

The research plan considers a least-redundant informational description of signals using a deterministic approach and without assuming any prior spectral knowledge. It provides a new notion of degrees of freedom that suits both band-limited and multi-band signals. It also extends this notion to higher dimensions to obtain information-theoretic bounds for space-time propagating signals. The roots of the project are in the classical theory of functional approximation and in the determination of the significant propagation modes of signals. The theory is connected to recent advancements in compressed sensing, and provides a unifying view of discrete and continuous signals as well as deterministic and probabilistic results. The foundational results of the project are relevant to both communication and remote sensing systems. The information-theoretic approach provides a baseline for what can be achieved in real systems.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction.

When Shannon laid the mathematical foundations of communication theory he embraced a probabilistic approach. A tangible consequence of this choice is that in today's communication systems performance is guaranteed in an average sense, or with high probability. Occasional violations from a specification are permitted, and cannot be avoided. This approach is well suited for consumer-oriented digital communication devices, where the occasional loss of data packets is not critical, and made Shannon's theory the golden standard to describe communication limits, and to construct codes that achieve these limits. The probabilistic approach, however, has also prevented Shannon's theory to be relevant in systems where occasional decoding errors can result in catastrophic failures, or in adversarial settings, where the behavior of the channel may be unknown and cannot be described by a probability distribution.

Intellectual Merit.

 With this motivation, in this project, we developed basic building blocks of a wave theory of information that have applications in the context of sensing, detection, and communication. We explored different deterministic measures that can represent the amount of information transported by waves and computed information-theoretic limits of signal reconstruction, detection, and sensing. We developed  a non-stochastic information theory that parallels Shannon's probabilistic theory of information, but that provides strict deterministic guarantees for every codeword transmission.

Specific outcomes.

Specifically, we looked at  a least redundant informational description of signals using a deterministic approach and without assuming any a priori spectral knowledge. We introduced a deterministic notion of degrees of freedom that suits both bandlimited and multi-band signals. We also  extended the treatment to higher dimensions and obtained information-theoretic bounds for space-time propagating signals. We then developed connections of the wave theory of blind sensing with recent advancements in the discrete setting of compressed sensing. Further developments included the extension of the deterministic approach to an information theory for control of dynamical systems and optimal decision theory.

Broad Impacts.

Our study has implications beyond the field of sensing and communications in terms of the introduction of new mathematical methods, and of their applicability to other fields of science. In laying the foundations for the wave theory of information, we have drawn connections between information theory, functional approximation, and compressed sensing. On the education front, we have educated new generations of students who, after graduation, occupied leading scientific positions in industry.
